DOC.HEAD: Factional Fighting Creates Crisis at Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Thee more people were killed in factional fighting in Natal Province, police said Wednesday, and a Parliament member said Natal's biggest hospital for blacks should be declared a disaster area. Carole Charlewood, who represents a Natal district for the anti-apartheid Democratic Party, said in a letter to the Health Ministry that the escalation of violence around the port city of Durban has aggravated already critical problems at King Edward VIII Hospital. She said the hospital staff is treating 20 to 30 gunshot victims a day, and patients were exposed to ``squalor, overcrowding and humiliation.'' ``The pressures on (operating) theaters and staff means that other patients requiring surgery must be bypassed, which has resulted in many unnecessary deaths,'' Mrs. Charlewood wrote. ``Patients also are dying because the intensive care unit facilities are hopelessly inadequate.'' The Health Ministry said Health Minister Rina Venter was aware of the problems at King Edward and giving them appropriate attention. Scores of blacks have been killed in and around the Durban-area township of Inanda this month, one of the worst surges of violence during a three-year power struggle in Natal between members of the relatively conservative Zulu organization Inkatha and supporters of militant anti-apartheid groups. About 2,500 people have been killed in the feud. The police unrest report Wednesday gave few details about the latest killings, saying one man was shot to death in the Durban-area township of Molweni and two killed in their home by attackers near the town of Richmond. On Tuesday, Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok toured battle-scarred sections of Inanda. He was accompanied by Mangosuthu Buthelezi, leader of Inkatha and chief minister of the semi-autonomous black homeland of KwaZulu. Vlok told reporters that poverty, high unemployment and ``appalling'' living conditions were a major factor behind the Inanda violence. But he said peace was unlikely unless ``there is a change of heart, away from hating one another.'' Buthelezi says he is as firmly opposed to apartheid as more militant groups aligned to the outlawed African National Congress. But he opposes the ANC's use of violence and its advocacy of confrontational tactics such as strikes, sanctions and demonstrations.
